column1: Modeling the complex interactions between users and items as well as amongst items themselves is at the core of designing successful recommender systems. One classical setting is predicting users' personalized sequential behavior (or 'next-item' recommendation)
column2: where the challenges mainly lie in modeling 'third-order' interactions between a user
column4: and the next item to consume. Existing methods typically decompose these higher-order interactions into a combination of pairwise relationships
column5: by way of which user preferences (user-item interactions) and sequential patterns (item-item interactions) are captured by separate components. In this paper
column8: to model such third-order relationships for large-scale sequential prediction. Methodologically
column9: we embed items into a 'transition space' where users are modeled as translation vectors operating on item sequences. Empirically
column10: this approach outperforms the state-of-the-art on a wide spectrum of real-world datasets. Data and code are available at https://sites.google.com/a/eng.ucsd.edu/ruining-he/.
